Frozen shoulder/dupuytrens contracture

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎11-04-2012 08:15 AM

I am a T1 insulin dependent for the past 22 yrs.  I was diagnosed with frozen shoulder about 3yrs ago and about 1 yr ago I was told I have Dupuytren contracture in both hands. I have been thru physical therapy 3 times for the shoulder with little improvement and now I have begun to have the same symptoms in both shoulders. I have read that both conditions are related to having diabetes (there was no injury to hand or shoulder that would explain reason for these conditions)  I have not expressed both issues with my ortho doc and would like to know if there is anyone experiencing or has experienced the same.

Helpful Response Given! Go to this response.

Report Inappropriate Content

Tracy - yes, I have ha both and Re: Frozen shoulder/dupuytrens contracture

‎11-04-2012 03:45 PM - edited ‎11-04-2012 03:47 PM

Tracey  Yes, I have had both capsulitis [frozen shoulder] and dupuytren's issues about 30 years ago.  First I had surgery on one shoulder, and then physical therapy.  I am a Type 1 for 55 years this month.

 

After surgery on one shoulder, and therapy on both  for several weeks I gave up that idea as it was just too painful for me. It may not be so for you,I hope not.  So, I went to a medical doctor who was licensed to provide acupuncture.  In three  weeks both shoulders were fine and still are today. The acupuncture did not hurt at all; very relaxing. 

 

For my hands: the doctor gave me this exercise that worked well for me.

I placed hands together and forced them backward & forward  as far as possible without pain; I did this about 10 to 15 times a day for several weeks.  I still use this exercise  but only once in a while to keep my fingers and hands flexible.  

 

I think though,  this hand exercise  depends on how severe a case we have. I found out about dupuytrin's while dealing with the shoulders. I was warned I could have serious problems with my hands.  It seems that the exercises I did kept my fingers straight; most of them, anyway. Two are bent slightly but I still have full use of my hands.

I wish the same results for you.  To catch the shoulder and hands  early on helped me a great deal. 

 

Best of Luck to you

Joan


* Type 1 Diagnosed for 57years as of Nov 2014
* 50 Year Type 1 Medalist Award from Joslin Diabetes Clinic (Harvard Medical School)
* Medtronic Paradigm Revel 523 insulin pump as of March 11, 2011
* Insulin: Humalog
* Food Allergies: milk, yeast, corn
* Hashimoto's thyroid disease
* A bit of arthritis
* One kidney due to benign Angiomyolipoma.
* Volunteer Community Disaster Co-Coordinator
* Hobbies/Interests: Wildlife Naturalists, artist, gardening, music

‎11-05-2012 09:06 AM

I've had frozen shoulder in both shoulders -- pre-diagnosis, but obviously related.  I tried to push off PT as long as I could the first time, but then started.  Took about 6 weeks for significant improvement with significant PT pain -- tears.  The thereapist asked if she should back down, and I said she had to rip the stuff up one way or another, so I would take as much as I could.  Second time I started earlier.  I was diligent in doing my exercises between sessions.  I'm sure I"m not 100% back, but my life is not impacted on a daily basis.  PT was extremely hard and painful, but worked for me.



You go to school to learn, not for a report card.
You use your meter to learn, not for a report card

Type 1 (LADA).. Novolog/Levemir

Adult onset T1

‎11-15-2012 02:46 PM

Thank you for replying to my question. I have been dealing with the frozen shoulder for 5+ years and recently start physical therapy which is very painful when the force stretching but do have some decrease in pain. I am having cortizone injection and pt tomorrow. My doctor and I may be discussing surgery if the pt doesn't work so I would like to know if it gave you any more range of motion?  Thank you for the idea or accupunture, as I thought about it at one time but have never know that much about it and its effects related to these conditions. I have been type 1 for 22 years and now that im in my 40's all these new things are happening.

 

                                                                    Thank You

Tracy,

 

This is a few days late, but watch the bg for unusual highs for the next few weeks after your cortisone shot.  I had a couple before my shoulder surgery this past spring and the cortisone really sent the bg up!  I had to really increase the basal for a while. 

 

I hope you get the relief you need.

gb2847
Diagnosed with Diabetes Type 2 by mistake --1/26/11
Diagnosed correctly with Type 1-- 4/5/11 (just before 47th birthday)
using OmniPod pump and Dexcom cgm
Also have Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy, Hashimoto's Thyroiditis, Asthma, Osteo Arthritis, Osteo Pinea, Gastroparesis, GERD, Hypersensitivity to irritants in environment (lungs, eyes), and Severe Obstructive Sleep Apnea

                                                          Thank You

                                                       Tracy Michaud

Tracy; To answer your current question.  I understand your conern as I had the same thoughts many years ago.  

 

It took about  20 years  for my shoulders to bind up with a good deal of pain after Dx as a T1D.   I was really worried.  I refused  cortisone as I had enough trouble with control in those days due to pain and stress of what may happen to me.

 

[Edited} My doctor said to me " do you want this over quickly with surgery or weeks to months of PT therapy?"   It took me seconds to chose surgery for the one shoulder affected. After surgery I also knew that PT would be painful for me.  So, I thought about acupuncture and found a medical doctor who could help me.  My insurance paid for the entire procedure b/c I sought only qualified doctors. 

 

Within a week of my first acupuncture Itreatment the shoulder could be used nromally with no pain at all; I included the other shoulder just in case.   Glad I did as no problem wiith the one shoulder ever.

 

Of course, we must all do what we feel  is best for ourself!! 

 

Hope I answered some of your concern.  Wishing  the best for you whatever you choose to do.

Joan


* Type 1 Diagnosed for 57years as of Nov 2014
* 50 Year Type 1 Medalist Award from Joslin Diabetes Clinic (Harvard Medical School)
* Medtronic Paradigm Revel 523 insulin pump as of March 11, 2011
* Insulin: Humalog

‎11-20-2012 06:48 PM

I wish I had seen this 2 days ago. I had my shot yesterday with ok sugar readings prior to shot. I did not take a reading until 6pm and it was so high it didn't register in my meter. I was feeling "fine" and hadn't eaten any thing that would have raised them to that level. By midnight I woke with potty issues for about an hour and after taking 12+ units at 6 my sugars were lower but still 500+. I had no idea cortisone shot could mess with bs. I am on my cycle so I though I either ate and didn't bolus or the high was because of my cycle. They tend to get higher at this time but never sent my off the chart. Luckily I didn't go into dka but Im finding it hard to believe that no dr even once mentioned I should take extra precautions when I receive cortisone. Thanks for the info and I will be talking to my endo dr about this in detail!!!
